characters: I/E. JACKIE'S MOTORCADE WASHINGTON, DC NIGHT
EDINBURGH, SOVIET FOREIGN MINISTER ANASTAS MIKOYAN, JEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACKIE KENNEDY. Jet-black bouffant, regal bearing, perfec symmetrical features. But the light behind her eyes has gone out. She walks alone, shuddering against a frigid wind. FADE TO BLACK. SUPER: Hyannis Port, Massachusetts 1963

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie -- black trim slacks, beige pullover sweater -- pa at the window. Finally, a cab pulls into the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: A JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - handsome yet rumpled

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: stands uneasily in

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kennedy? They told me to come up. She studies his unkempt appearance, but doesn't answer. T Journalist is perplexed but strains to be gentle...

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry for your loss.

dialogues.speaker: I.
dialogues.text: Jackie takes a long moment -- her voice raw...

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Have you read what they've been writing? Krock and Merriman and all the rest?

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Yes. I have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merriman is such a bitter man. It's been just one week and already they're treating him like some dusty old artifact, to be shelved away. (beat) That's no way to be remembered.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: And how would you like him remembered, Mrs. Kennedy? Suddenly stern, authoritative --

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: You understand that I will be editing this conversation? (beat) Just in case I don’t say exactly what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: With all due respect that seems very unlikely, Mrs. Kennedy. Jackie stares at him, polite but firm.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Right. Okay. So this will be your own version of...what happened. Holding his gaze, she refocuses, preparing for a performa of sorts.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Exactly. Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie and the Journalist sit across from each other at a table. She smokes a cigarette, lost in the horrible memor

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I thought it was another backfire. (beat) I very nearly didn’t go. What if I'd been here, or out riding in Virginia somewhere? (beat) Thank God I was with him... She trails off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, thank God? Instead of an answer-.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Do you know what I think of history?

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Of history?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I've read a great deal. More than people realize. The more I read, the more I wonder: When something is written down, does that make it true?

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: It's all that we have.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Had. We have television now. Now people can see with their own eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: That tour of the White House you did a couple of years ago, for CBS, I always assumed you did that for...a purpose? No? After the fashion magazines? You even won an Emmy...

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I didn’t do that program for me. I did it for the American people.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: That program was my first glimpse into the White House and for whatever it’s worth, I thought you were excellent, very poised.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Thank you. An afterthought...

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: You could have had a career as a broadcaster. I’m sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? The Journalist looks up from his notes.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: (nervous) I said...you could have had a career as a broadcaster.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Are you giving me professional advice? He shakes his head, embarrassed...

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: I’m not. (beat) But I’m sure that the whole country would like to know what you're going to do next.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I can assure you -- not television. She takes another drag of her cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie is a year younger -- at the height of her legendar beauty -- wearing a floor-length, scarlet gown.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Welcome to the White House. Behind her are LIGHTS and BOOM MIC’s -- a full-blown TELEVISION PRODUCTION. She stands face to face with NANCY TUCKERMAN, her social secretary. Life-long friends, Nancy is Jackie's less stylish, less successful sister. Displeased with the sound of her voice, Jackie lifts her shoulders, her posture more erect. She tries again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to the White House. We’re so proud to call it home. Her brow furrows, still dissatisfied.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Why don’t you try ‘the people's house’? Make it more personal. Jackie considers the suggestion. And now -- with that notorious, breathy diction...

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Welcome to the people's house. We're so proud to call it home. (beat) Better? Nancy nods.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When will Jack join us?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: They want to hear from you. Jackie is skeptical

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: They think I’m a fool -- one year in office, wasting their money.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: That's why you need to show them what you've done. Nancy can tell Jackie is still uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The President will join you in the Monroe Room. At the end of the tour. You'll be great. Jackie smiles, grateful and takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Stay close.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Of course. You look beautiful. Jackie walks onto set and the TV LIGHTS turn ON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: **This is the legendary White House tour, broadcast by CB February 14, 1962, to an audience of 56 million people** CHARLES COLLINGSWOOD of CBS NEWS narrates over black and white footage.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINGSWOOD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This is the White House as seen from its South Lawn. For the next hour Mrs. John F. Kennedy invites you to visit the President's House and see some of the restorations she’s made in its interior. Mrs. John F. Kennedy, third youngest of the twenty-nine wives to live in the White House. Jackie's beauty has been magnified ten-fold. Her nerves h vanished. She smiles, radiant, and the show is on...

dialogues.speaker: COLLINGSWOOD
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kennedy I want to thank you for letting us visit your official home. (beat) This is obviously the room from which most of your work on it is directed... All around them, ANTIQUE FURNITURE is arranged in various states of restoration and disrepair.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: (playful) Yes, it's attic and the cellar all in one. Since our work started we received hundreds of letters every day. This is where we evaluate all of the finds and see if we want to keep them if they'll fit into our budget.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINGSWOOD
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kennedy, every first lady and every administration since President Madison's time, has made changes greater or smaller in the White House. Jackie steals a glance off-camera. With a quiet gesture — Nancy reminds her to smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before we look at some of the changes you've made...What's your basic plan? A beat, as Jackie considers her motivation. And then, fro the heart -

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Well, I really don't have one. Because I think this house will always grow and should. It just seemed to me such a shame when we came here, to find hardly anything of the past in the house. Hardly anything before 19-2. off-camera Nancy looks at her notes, nodding along to Jackie's words.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINGSWOOD
dialogues.text: Now suppose you and your committee were to acquire some of the things that are in this room, what happens when the next President’s wife comes into the White House?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Well if they don’t want it...in the past, you see, they could sell it or throw it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie continues the interview with the Journalist.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: And the talk of the tax payer money being wasted?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I raised every dime privately that we spent on that restoration. I loved that house and wanted to share it with the American people. To impart a sense of America’s greatness. (beat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Objects and artifacts last far longer than people and they represent important ideas in history, identity...beauty. He scribbles down her remarks -- all cold, abstract ideas And then, probing, trying to find the emotion...

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: I’m sure the readers would like to know... What it’s like to be a member of your family? Jackie thinks -- and then...

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Imagine a little boy surrounded by all this. Having his older brother die in battle and then going off to that same war and coming home a hero. People see that little boy, born to wealth, privilege, willing to sacrifice everything for his ideals and service to his nation.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Royalty. You make it sound like royalty.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Well for royalty you need tradition. And for tradition you need time.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Well I guess it has to start somewhere, right? There has to be a day one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie and Collingswood now stand in the sprawling East R

dialogues.speaker: COLLINGSWOOD
dialogues.text: This is the East Room, pretty much as Americans have known it now for sixty years. Obviously you haven't felt like you had to make any great changes in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I think it's lovely. I hate to make changes really, so when you find a room like this, it's wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINGSWOOD
dialogues.text: This piano brings to mind that this is the part of the White House where you have the musical affairs?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: That's right this piano was designed by Franklin Roosevelt with the Eagle’s Support. (beat) And this is the end of the room where Pablo Casals played for us, where we had a portable stage built for us, when we had the Shakespeare Players.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINGSWOOD
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kennedy, this administration has shown a particular affinity for artists, musicians, writers, and poets. Behind the camera, Nancy tracks Jackie’s every move.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINGSWOOD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is this because you and your husband just feel that way. Or do you think there's a relationship between the government and the arts? Jackie pauses -- clearly hesitant to tread on any ground resembling public policy.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: That's so complicated. I-I don't know. (beat) I just think that everything in the White House should be the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The East Room at its most glamorous.  10. Jackie is seated in the first row of an audience listenin Pablo Casals play Felix Mendelssohn's Piano Trio No. 1 in minor, Op. 49. Jackie is transfixed. Happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy watches Jackie speak to Collingswood.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: And if it's an American company that you can help, I like to do that. If it’s not...Just as long as it's the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUSH IN on Jackie, basking in Casal’s performance. captivated. The final note. The music ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The interview continues inside. She sits on the couch now across from the Journalist.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Is your faith helping you?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I'd prefer to discuss my faith with a priest. You're not a man of the cloth, are you?

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: No, I'm not. I’m just trying to get to the truth. That’s what reporters do.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: The truth? Well I’ve grown accustomed to a great divide between what people believe and what I know to be real.  ll.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Fine, I will settle for a story that’s believable.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: That's more like it. You know I used to be a reporter myself once. I know what you're looking for.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: (confused) I’m sorry?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: A moment-by-moment account. That’s what you came her for, isn’t it? (beat) You want me to describe the sound the bullet made when it collided with my husband's skull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie applies makeup in the mirror while practicing a sp in Spanish. Her delivery is practiced, careful.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I’m very happy to be in the great state of Texas, to be with you and experience the noble Spanish tradition that has achieved so much in Dallas. This tradition started 100 years ago before the colonization of Massachusetts, my husband’s State. It is a tradition that remains alive and strong. She puts on her famous pink, pillbox hat and closes the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie walks through the plane. She can hear the loud cro outside.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: (hopeful) Is that the sound of birds? Playing along with his wife --  12.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT KENNEDY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Not exactly birds. Must be the ocean... (beat) Are you ready?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: (ironic) Of course. I love crowds. The door opens. Jackie walks off AIR FORCE ONE onto the tarmac at LOVE FIELD. It is NOVEMBER 22, 1963. She is wearing that pink wool Chanel suit with navy lapel an outfit that will soon be notorious but right now, in t morning light, is cheery and elegant, another fashion pronouncement by the most stylish woman in America. Beside her is her husband, PRESIDENT JOHN F. KENNEDY. Jackie absorbs the roar of the crowd like a physical assa Then sees GOVERNOR JOHN CONNALLY and his wife NELLIE wait at the bottom of the short staircase, flanked by a saluti honor guard. The crowds are chanting "JACK-EE! JACK-EE!"

dialogues.speaker: LYNDON JOHNSON
dialogues.text: You remember the Governor and Mrs. Connally?

dialogues.speaker: LADYBIRD
dialogues.text: Welcome to Dallas, Darling. She carefully descends to the bottom of the stairs, where suddenly -- Nellie thrusts a bouquet of RED ROSES into he hands. A beat, as she eyes the crimson blossoms. And then -- shouting over the screaming crowd...

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: My! What a welcome! The Governor places a conspiratorial arm around the Presi and holds him for a whispered conference. Amidst the chaos, Jackie turns around to face the CROWD, which erupts in even louder cheers. She blushes, almost embarrassed, and responds with a demure smile.  13. Then she notices -- the President is on the move again. S hurries to catch up as he marches toward the waiting limo Jackie holds a grin in place and methodically makes eye contact with every voter on the rope line --

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you. Thank you so much for coming...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The interview with Journalist continues. Her voice quiver a stream of consciousness...

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: There’d been the biggest motorcade from the airport. Hot, wild like in Mexico or Vienna. The sun was strong in our faces but I couldn't wear my sunglasses. Jack has his hand out and I see a piece of his skull come off. It wasn’t flesh colored, it wasn’t white. He slumps in my lap. His blood, his brains in my lap. And I’m saying Jack, Jack can you hear me, Jack, I love you Jack! (through tears) And his head was so beautiful, and his mouth was beautiful and his eyes were open. I was trying to keep the top of his head down. Keep it all in. He had the most wonderful expression on his face, you know? Just before they'd ask him a question, just before he’d answer. He looked puzzled. (beat) I knew he was dead. She lights a cigarette. The Journalist looks up from his notes.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: (clears throat) Mrs. Kennedy--

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Don’t think for one second I’m going to let you publish that. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) You understand?

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. I understand. The Journalist looks down.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What did the bullet sound like? PUSH IN on Jackie and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BANG! -- two motorcycles speed up to the President's Limousine as it races to the hospital. Jackie sits in back. Her husband’s head is in her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TIGHT CLOSE-UP of Jackie. Her wide-set, deep brown eyes are blank, exhausted. Her mascara is streaked, her cheeks scarred with red-brow smudges. The dried blood of her dead husband. She stares herself in the mirror. The pillbox hat is gone -- cast on the floor -- and her usually perfect hair is tousled. Frantically, she scrubs at the blood, some of it still we with Kleenex. She wipes at her reflection in the mirror. Finally, she pats her face dry with a hanging towel. Then noticing her hair, she attempts to restore its shape with hands. Her hands quiver. Frustrated, she lets out a wrenching SOB. And then -~ KNO

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kennedy? Are you alright? It's Larry... She takes in a breath, forcing her composure.  15.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I'll be ready in a moment. LARRY O'BRIEN, the President's Congressional Liaison and family friend, speaks to her from the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Take all of the time you need. With her fingers she wipes the tears and blood from under eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Are they waiting? Jackie stares at herself in the mirror -- a macabre distortion of the picture from Love Field that morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACKIE'S POV -- PRESIDENT LYNDON JOHNSON, his wife LADY B his aide JACK VALENTI. CONGRESSMEN ALBERT THOMAS and JACK BROOKS, stand by JUDGE SARAH HUGHES, who holds up a small bible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: President Johnson hesitates -- but there's no choice. He places his hand on the bible. Jackie pulls back her shoulders, holding herself erect.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE HUGHES
dialogues.text: I do, solemnly swear... President Johnson's deep Texas drawl is uncharacteristica soft, subdued. He repeats every line after Judge Hughes.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT JOHNSON
dialogues.text: I do solemnly swear...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE HUGHES
dialogues.text: That I will faithfully execute...

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT JOHNSON
dialogues.text: That I will faithfully execute...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE HUGHES
dialogues.text: The office of President of the United States...

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT JOHNSON
dialogues.text: The Office of President of the United States...  16.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE HUGHES
dialogues.text: And will to the best of my ability...

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT JOHNSON
dialogues.text: And will to the best of my ability...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE HUGHES
dialogues.text: Preserve...

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Preserve...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE HUGHES
dialogues.text: Protect...

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Protect...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE HUGHES
dialogues.text: And defend...

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT JOHNSON
dialogues.text: And defend...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE HUGHES
dialogues.text: The Constitution of the United States...

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT JOHNSON
dialogues.text: The Constitution of the United States...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE HUGHES
dialogues.text: So help me God...

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT JOHNSON
dialogues.text: So help me God... Johnson kisses his wife, then places his hand on Jackie's A FLASHBULB erupts, capturing the moment. PRESIDENT JOHNSON (CONT’D) Let’s start the engines and get some of the heat off this plane. Thank you. Valenti shakes President Johnson’s hand and addresses him

dialogues.speaker: VALENTI
dialogues.text: Mr. President.  17. Jackie's eyes drift downward, blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Air Force One is airborne. Jackie sits, staring straight ahead. Suddenly she rises and approaches CLINT HILL, the head of Secret Service detail.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Agent Hill? Can you tell me...what. size was the bullet? A beat of silence, everyone unsettled.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t think it was a thirty eight, was it? What do you call it? The caliber? It seemed bigger. It seemed like something soldiers would use or maybe it was the kind they use for deer hunting....

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: (very careful) Mrs. Kennedy, you don’t have to-- we don’t know yet. No one answers. She becomes distant, lost in concentratio She turns to her husband's oldest friends, the IRISH MAFI KENNY O'DONNELL, O’Brien, and DAVE POWERS.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: We need to have the Irish Cadets.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Yes. The Irish Cadets -- for the funeral. Jack loved them. He saw them perform in Dublin last summer.

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Of course, Mrs. Kennedy. We'll make sure of it.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: And those bagpipers from Scotland. What were they called, Kenny?  18.

dialogues.speaker: O'DONNELL
dialogues.text: Yeah. The Black Watch.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: That's right. The Black Watch Pipers. Hill approaches --

dialogues.speaker: HILL
dialogues.text: When we arrive, we'll be exiting out the rear of the plane. You, the President -- President Johnson that is, Mrs. Johnson--

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: --Why the rear?

dialogues.speaker: HILL
dialogues.text: There's press at Andrews. Not to mention the security risk--

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I'm supposed to hide away. Now?

dialogues.speaker: HILL
dialogues.text: Not hide-- Jackie's voice rises, an unexpected anger-~

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: --I'm sure those people would love that. What do they call themselves? The Birch Society? No, I will not sneak out the back door. (beat, final) I'll go out the usual way. We all will. Hill is about to argue, but Jackie stares back at him -- defiant -- and he realizes it's a lost cause.

dialogues.speaker: HILL
dialogues.text: I'll arrange it. And now ADMIRAL GEORGE BURKLEY interjects--

dialogues.speaker: BURKLEY
dialogues.text: When we land, Mrs. Kennedy, we'll need to proceed directly to the hospital for the autopsy.  19.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: (aghast) The autopsy? (beat) Is that necessary?

dialogues.speaker: BURKLEY
dialogues.text: I'm afraid it's required.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: By who?

dialogues.speaker: BURKLEY
dialogues.text: The law, Mrs. Kennedy. She considers this. And then --

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: And what exactly will they do? Burkley hesitates -- looks to the others for help -- but one knows what she means.

dialogues.speaker: BURKLEY
dialogues.text: I’m not sure--

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: --What does an ‘autopsy’ entail? I want you to explain to me. I want all of the details. I’m his wife - or whatever I am now. (beat) I want all the details. Will they slice him open?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LADY BIRD JOHNSON approaches. Nearly 20 years Jackie's senior, she is a warm, maternal presence. Lady Bird moves toward Jackie as if she might give her a - but stops short, repulsed by the gore that still clings Jackie's dress.

dialogues.speaker: LADY BIRD
dialogues.text: Oh, Darling. She takes Jackie's hand, instead.

dialogues.speaker: LADY BIRD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can I send someone back to help you change? Before we land? Jackie glances down at her dress and seems to take in the horror again, for the first time.  20.

dialogues.speaker: LADY BIRD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All those cameras... People will be watching. But Jackie is lost in her own world...

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: There were wanted posters. Everywhere. For Jack. With Jack's face on them.....

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let them see what they've done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie remains seated as the plane comes to a halt She watches as a FORKLIFT passes by, headed to the rear o the plane where it will unload her husband's casket. Suddenly, from the front of the plane, she hears --

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jackie?! Where's Jackie? She rises -- as ATTORNEY GENERAL ROBERT KENNEDY, his face streaked with tears -- comes rushing down the aisle

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Bobby! She collapses into his arms and buries herself into his shoulder. Amidst the noisy chaos of the now-crowded cabin they are quiet. And then -- the rear door swings open, letting in a gust cold November air. The FORKLIFT is positioned directly outside, and several MEN now step onto the plane and take hold of the CASKET. An AIR FORCE OFFICER, in charge of the Crew, informs Bobb

dialogues.speaker: AF OFFICER
dialogues.text: Sir, there's a car waiting on the tarmac to take you and Mrs. Kennedy to Bethesda. Jackie is suddenly panicked --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to AF Officer) Mrs. Kennedy and I will ride with the casket. In the ambulance. 21. O'Brien pulls Bobby aside, but still in earshot of Jackie

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: Valenti wants to know how we are going to handle the exit.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: The exit?

dialogues.speaker: O'BRIEN
dialogues.text: He says Johnson wants to talk to the press. Jackie takes Bobby's arm..

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (to O'Brien) He can exit however he wants. We're leaving now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie and Bobby sit on either side of the CASKET. of calm after the frenzy at Andrews. Suddenly, it occurs to her --

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: The casket will be closed won't it? At the funeral?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: We can sort that all out later.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I want it closed so badly, Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I'm not sure it can be. For a Head of State... Bobby's exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: There was blood everywhere. There were so many pieces. Still rattled himself, Bobby tries to comfort her... A moment  22.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Jackie...

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I tried to hold his head together. The Ambulance hits a pot-hole, and the Casket slides -- slamming into Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (to Driver, upset) Hey! Slow down. They sit in silence, staring straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie looks in anguish at the door that leads to the operating room. She is surrounded by family and friends but nobody dares speak. Next to her is Nancy. Also BENJAMIN and TONI BRADL close friends. JANET LEE and HUGH AUCHINCLOSS, JACKIE'S mother and step-father. PAM TURNURE, JACKIE'S press secretary and MARY GALLAGHER, her private secretary. DOCT JOHN WALSH, her personal doctor. O'Brien and O'Donnell ar also present, along with DEFENSE SECRETARY ROBERT MACNAMA Everyone looks at the door. As it opens and closes we see the hospital personnel carrying supplies and equipment fo the autopsy. What follows unfolds in a splintered haze of grief... A TV set blasts the news.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER CRONKITE
dialogues.text: (on television) The President was lying motionless in the car. Mrs. Kennedy was leaning over him fully. Connelly was in the backseat holding his stomach with both hands. Inside the emergency room witnesses said the First Lady was splattered with blood

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie walks down the hospital hall, drawn toward the aut room. But Bobby retrieves her...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Jackie, Jackie...  23.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Make sure they make him look like himself. All around her, the room divides into smaller groups. Dr. Walsh, Ben Bradlee, O'Brien, and Macnamara break off. Bob confers with O'Brien and O'Donnell. Jackie finds herself surrounded by Pam, Nancy, Mary, Toni her mother.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (anxious) Where are the children?

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: They're with Maud. She's taken them to the house in Georgetown.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I'd rather them at home. Their routine shouldn't be disrupted.

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: Yes. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I'll see to it.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: What do they know? No one answers. Dr. Walsh approaches and greets her.

dialogues.speaker: DR. WALSH
dialogues.text: You need some rest. Handing her something...

dialogues.speaker: DR. WALSH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is there water? Jackie accepts the pill, eyeing it in her palm. She delicately swallows it. She drifts through the room towards Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: It had to be some silly little Communist... (beat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If he'd been killed for civil rights... At least then it would have meant something. You know? Wistful, weighed down with regret --

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jack warned me. Said we were going to ‘nut country.’ But I thought it was all going so well. Fort Worth. In Houston. All the problems Adlai had -- Jack was winning them over. Bobby tries to calm her down.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They kept handing me yellow roses. Yellow roses. At every stop. Yellow roses. Then in Dallas... Jackie trails off...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I know. Hey let’s turn this off. Bobby turns off the television. And now -- he whispers to Jackie, his own rage boiling over...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They want a show of grief. They’re already asking about funeral arrangements! Jackie storms towards the operating room. At the last moment, right as the door opens and she sees body of her husband, she CRIES out -- and Bobby pulls her back. He holds her, consoling her. Later -- everyone sits the waiting room, once again watch the news.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER CRONKITE
dialogues.text: (on television) President Johnson met with Secretary of State Rusk. Minutes later there was a hastily added conference with Secretary of Defense McNamara. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: WALTER CRONKITE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Even at a time of sorrow the harsh facts of the Cold War do not allow a pause in overseeing the affairs of Defense and Foreign Policy. There seems little doubt that McNamara will stay on under Mr. Johnson...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ambulance carrying the PRESIDENT'S CASKET now winds through the darkened streets of our nation's Capital. Next to Jackie in the back of the ambulance, Bobby is in daze.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Lyndon's people are claiming I told him to take the oath in Dallas. Asshole couldn't wait and now they’re blaming me for it. Jackie looks out at the glowing MONUMENTS, passing rows o AMERICAN FLAGS outside government offices, all flying at mast. Suddenly Jackie lowers the glass barrier separating them the DRIVER.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: (to Driver) Excuse me. Do you know who James Garfield was? A beat of hesitation, confused.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: No, Ma’am. She looks to the Nurse.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Do you know who William McKinley was? Or what he did? No answer. The Driver glances back to Bobby, looking for help, but none is coming.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They were both US Presidents killed while they were in office. (beat) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And what about Abraham Lincoln? Do you know what he did?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: (relieved) He won the Civil War. He abolished slavery, Ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: That's right. Thank you. Jackie raises the glass barrier. She turns to Bobby --

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bobby, please tell them I want the books on Lincoln. About his funeral. Once again, they sit in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Motorcade comes to a stop outside the White House whe MARINE HONOR GUARD has taken up position. INT. HALLWAY - KID’S ROOM - WHITE HOUSE Jackie arrives at John Jr's room. Carefully opens the doo and peeks in. He’s sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie, alone, surveys her bedroom. Her WEDDING PHOTO sit on one night-stand, PHOTOS OF JOHN JR and CAROLINE on the other. Finally, one button at-at-time, she undresses and the Cha Suit falls to the ground in a bloody heap. She cries as she takes off her stained stockings. She scrubs furiously at the blood under her nails. She steps into the shower and the frosted glass door shut behind her. She turns on the water. Blood races from her hair down he back. CLOSE ON Jackie as water pounds her face...  27. She walks back through her room in a nightdress. She lights a cigarette and lies down in bed with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie smokes as the Journalist finishes scribbling. A be of silence, and then --

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: You'll have to share something personal, eventually. People won't stop asking until you do.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: And if I don’t they’ll interpret my silence however they want? (beat) Her brow furrows. Her lips are drawn. She holds back her tears...but she can’t hide her anger.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Most writers want to be famous.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Do you want to be famous?

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: No I’m fine as I am, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: You should prepare yourself, this article will bring you a great deal of attention.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: In that case, any advice for me?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Yes. (beat) Don't marry the President. The journalist looks down, nervous and uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you afraid I’m about to cry?  28.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: No, I'd say you're more likely to scream.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Scream what?

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: My husband was a great man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON an etching of LINCOLN’S FUNERAL PROCESSION. BILL WALTON -- Jackie's dear friend and cultural advisor traces the route as he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: WALTON
dialogues.text: Lincoln’s funeral catafalque departed the White House, and progressed along Pennsylvania Avenue to the Capitol. Jackie stands next to him. Her fair skin pops dramaticall against her chic black dress -- accidentally the most beautiful widow in the world. WALTON (CONT’D) The next day it returned to the White House, and then they walked all the way to St. Matthew’s in a long, grand procession. It was a sunny spring day. Only six hundred tickets were allotted, but thousands lined the streets and rooftops. Citizens, Senators, Congressman, Diplomats and Officers -- all in their full dress uniforms. Walton picks up a photograph.

dialogues.speaker: WALTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lincoln’s mount, ‘Old Bob’ was draped in a black blanket with white trim and tassels. Hooded, he was led riderless at the head of a miles-long procession by the Reverend Henry Brown.  29. Jackie stops to examine a PAINTING of LINCOLN’S CASKET ly in state.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I can feel Jack getting angry with us. ‘There you go, spending all that money on those silly little knick-nacks... (beat) The man would spend whatever it took for votes, but balked at buying a beautiful painting. (beat) I guess we don't have to worry about that anymore. Walton has no idea what to say.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We must get this right, Bill. we must get this right. It has to be beautiful. (beat) Did you tell them we'll need a horse-drawn carriage? We have to march with Jack. Everyone. A big beautiful procession that people will remember.

dialogues.speaker: WALTON
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kennedy... You don't have to do this.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: WALTON
dialogues.text: In fact, I don’t think they'll let you parade through the streets. (beat) The world's gone mad. You should take the children and disappear. Build a fortress in Boston and never look back. Jackie sees the deep concern in his eyes. Before she can respond there’s a knock -—-

dialogues.speaker: NANCY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kennedy? Jackie turns to her old friend.  30.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Are the children awake?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: They're playing in Caroline's room. Jackie considers this -- knows she can't avoid the inevit any longer.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: How do I do this? Nancy takes Jackie's arm to comfort her.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh dear. It doesn't matter what you say. Just hug them and tell them it will be okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie walks with Nancy toward her daughter's bedroom -- fierce determination in her eyes. She is the executioner, about to kill her own children's innocence. She stops at the threshold of her daughter's bedroom, abo to barge in -- and stops cold. INSIDE -- CAROLINE (5) and JOHN JR. (nearly 3) are drawin with MAUD SHAW, their longtime nanny. Jackie gives them one more moment, and then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --steps inside. The children both turn and rush toward he with delighted squeals. While Jackie embraces them, in hushed tones...

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What do they know?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I tried to explain to Caroline last night. She keeps asking for him. But she doesn't understand. Jackie hugs and kisses Caroline and John Jr., leading the the bedside so she can sit at eye-level with them.  31.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Mommy... Why are you dressed so funny?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Something very sad has happened. And this is how we dress when something sad happens. JOHN JR. Mommy, where's Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Daddy won't be coming home.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Why not? Jackie struggles.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Daddy had to go see your baby brother Patrick. In heaven.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Because I'm here with you. And we don't want Patrick to get lonely, do we?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: But what about us?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Caroline, I need you to be a big girl. You can be brave, right? You can be a soldier? (beat) A very bad man hurt Daddy. Daddy would come home if he could. But he can't. He has to go to heaven. Some understanding is beginning to build.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Can I say goodbye?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Yes, of course you can, my love.  32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room has been transformed into a hall of mourning. Walton has added some additional touches since the night before -- looping BLACK CREPE along the molding, a catafa where the Shakespeare stage would have stood. Jackie is seated with Caroline, John Jr, and Bobby. (Present are once again Jackie's parents, Janet and Hugh Auchincloss, and her half-brother JAMES AUCHINCLOSS. But KENNEDY CLAN is now also here in full. Bobby and Ethel, TEDDY and JOAN, PAT and her husband PETER, and their moth ROSE. Behind the family are close aides O'Brien, O'Donnel and Powers, along with their wives.) John Jr, a restless boy, gets up and walks through the ro with a mischievous smile. Bobby follows, scoops him up and returns him to their sea Jackie holds John Jr’s hand and pulls Caroline closer. A beat -- as Jackie clocks the anguish and pity on the fa around her. She lowers her eyes unable to bear it.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER KUHN
dialogues.text: Requiem eternam dona eis, Domine, et lux perpetua luceat eis. Te decet hymnus Deus, in Sion, et tibi reddetur votum in Terusalem...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The immediate family has retired to the White House Residence. Jackie stands with Bobby and Rose, the matriarch of the Kennedy clan. Caroline and John Jr. play with Maude nearb

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: That was a beautiful mass. Jackie is drained and exhausted. The adrenaline of the previous day and night has long since worn off. And now Bobby notices -- across the room, President Johns aide, Jack Valenti, waits in the doorway. BOBBY (CONT’D) Excuse me, mother. Jackie.  33. As Bobby crosses the room and confers with Valenti, Jacki remains in her reverie. Rose turns to her...

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Have you started on the guest list for the burial?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: The what?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: You'll need to pare it down, dear. We can’t possibly accommodate all these people at Brookline.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTI
dialogues.text: (hushed, but firm) We need to discuss the funeral. We all want to follow her lead. But, we still don't know much about this Oswald. There may be co- conspirators.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: (impatient, dismissive) I'll talk to her, but she makes the call.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTI
dialogues.text: There's also the matter of the oval.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do first -- plan the funeral or pack the furniture?

dialogues.speaker: VALENTI
dialogues.text: I know this is all delicate. That's why I'm approaching you. (beat) But a procession is insane.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Brookline?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: The family plot. I assume Jack will be buried with the rest of us. Jackie absorbs this, silent, staring across the room. Fol her gaze to --  34.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTI
dialogues.text: I just can’t have my President walking. Crowd full of people. Given what’s happened.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Your President?

dialogues.speaker: VALENTI
dialogues.text: My President.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Well, regardless of what happens, my brother is going to be carried in a box.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTI
dialogues.text: And I am sorry sir--

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Fuck off, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO --
dialogues.text: Jackie watches Valenti leave the room. Around her -- a new conversation - mother, Janet --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy, Mary, and her

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: Averell Harriman owns at least four properties in Georgetown. I'm sure he could loan out one of them? Jackie seems completely oblivious --

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I'll ask Sarge to look into it. I'm sure we have time. They can't expect us to move immediately, can they?

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: Of course not. Don't be silly. And then suddenly --

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Lincoln's widow died destitute. The others quiet, all turning to her.  35.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She moved back to Illinois. Had to sell all her furniture. And the Van Buren's and the Tyler's too. (beat) She auctioned it off, piece-by- piece, just to keep a roof over her head.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: That will never happen to you. But Jackie's not listening...

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: The collectors we bought it from... Remember? Bill and I had to haggle for every sofa and every chair. (beat) If I sell some of it back now, maybe I can put Caroline and John through school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie and Collingswood stands at the bottom of the stair to the second-floor Residence.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINGSWOOD
dialogues.text: This staircase goes up to the second floor, which I know are reserved for the private living of the President and his family. I don't think any television cameras or motion picture cameras have ever gone up there, cause that’s where you live.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: That's right. A beat, as she stares at the wall, lined with portraits tracking the slow deterioration of ABRAHAM LINCOLN--

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here is what the White House did to President Lincoln. Here is how he changed. (beat) 1861. The strong man with the arched eyebrow. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) 1865. One week before his assassination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie leads Collingswood into the Lincoln Bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINGSWOOD
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kennedy, do you spend a great deal of time in the Lincoln room?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: It was where we lived when we first came here, when our rooms at the other end of the hall were being painted...

dialogues.speaker: COLLINGSWOOD
dialogues.text: It's a nice room. Was this a bedroom during Lincoln's time?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: No it was Lincoln's cabinet room.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINGSWOOD
dialogues.text: Are all the pieces from Lincoln's time?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Yes, they are. The most famous one, of course, is the Lincoln bed. It was bought by Mrs. Lincoln. Along with the dressing bureaus, and chair, and this table. She bought a lot of furniture for this house which made her husband rather cross because he thought she spent too much money. Jackie turns to a small desk in the corner. A new reveren in her voice --

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And on the table is the Gettysburg Address. CLOSE ON -- those hallowed words.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is probably the greatest treasure in this room. (beat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And this sofa, and these two chairs. Lincoln They were sold in that sale I was telling you about. And they went to England and through man who all the descendants of the brought them there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby sits behind press coverage... Here he Bobby looks up to Bobby? Here he again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: his desk watching the ongoing marathon of

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: comes, here he comes. see Jackie standing in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: comes out and down the hall

dialogues.speaker: LEE HARVEY OSWALD, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: I really don’t know what this situation is about. Nobody has told me accused I don't anything except that I’m of...

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: mean to upset your mother. But Brookline is no place to bury a President. Bobby looks at her. He’s tired. Quiet. The TV interrupts them. A REPORTER shouting a question to Oswald... Did you

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: kill the President?

dialogues.speaker: LEE HARVEY OSWALD, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: No I have not been charged with that. that to In fact, nobody has said me yet. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LEE HARVEY OSWALD, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: First thing I heard about it was when the newspaper reporters in the hall..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sea of familiar WHITE CROSSES the 420 acres of ARLINGTO NATIONAL CEMETERY are shrouded in RAIN and MIST.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A motorcade of BLACK LINCOLNS winds through the rows of graves, finally pulling to a stop. Jackie strides forth under a canopy of umbrellas, accompa by Bobby and Walton. She's greeted by the cemetery's SUPERINTENDENT JOHN METZL soaked to the bone.

dialogues.speaker: METZLER
dialogues.text: (nervous, awkward) Welcome to Arlington, Mrs. Kennedy. Jackie shivers in the damp cold.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie leads a long procession of AIDES and SECRET SERVIC trudging through the mud and endless graves.

dialogues.speaker: METZLER
dialogues.text: The third option is just down there. At the base of the hill. Ahead is a sprawling green slope, atop of which is ROBERT LEE'S MANSION, a massive Greek-Revival structure of white marble, with 8 thick, imposing Athenian columns. Metzler stops at the base of the hill, and the others sur the surroundings.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What do you think Ken?

dialogues.speaker: O'DONNELL
dialogues.text: I did like Dewey Circle. If we could get rid of the leaves in time.  39.

dialogues.speaker: METZLER
dialogues.text: Problem there is not just the leaves. It's the access roads. CLOSE ON Jackie -- as the mens’ voices now FADE, a trance settling. Suddenly, Jackie steps out from under the umbrellas -- in the rain -- inexorably drawn toward the hill.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Jackie?! But she ignores him. Bobby grabs an umbrella, struggling follow and keep her under cover. BOBBY (CONT’D) Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: He can’t just be buried anywhere. He deserves more. They keep walking.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Watch your step. She stumbles. BOBBY (CONT’D) Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: My shoes are sticking in the mud. She keeps walking. Finally, she's at the front of LEE MANSION staring down. JACKIE'S POV -- endless graves and mist below. Jackie makes eye contact with Walton. He simply nods. Walton turns to Metzler, who's holding a wooden STAKE. Metzler hands him the stake, and Walton walks directly to spot in the center of the hill, driving it into the groun But Jackie isn’t satisfied. She pulls out the stake, walk few feet to the right, and drives it back into the ground It’s settled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie Portman and Peter Sarsgaard

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie Portman

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie Portman

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy Crudup and Natalie Portman

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie Portman

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max Casella, Beth Grant, Peter Sarsgaard, Natalie Portman  40. Jackie walks with Bobby through the cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I think maybe you should talk to a Priest.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Maybe. (beat) Bobby, I want to talk to the press.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: No. You let Dave handle that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Journalist scribbles while Jackie talks...

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: You know... that first night, Bob McNamara, he said he'd buy back our old house for us in Georgetown. (beat) I don’t really have things. I don't even have a home.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: And what about this house?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: This? It’s awfully cold.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Well you could light a fire. Invite people over. The parties that you threw at the White House, nobody had ever seen anything like that. Private concerts with artists and friends drinking champagne and singing-

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Are you suggesting I throw a party?

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Well, no, not now, obviously. I’m only suggesting that you've brought life to a cold house before.  4l.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: That house wasn’t mine. Neither is this one. (beat) Nothing is ever mine. Not to keep, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Leaving that house must have been very difficult.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: A First Lady must always be ready to pack her suitcases. It’s inevitable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie and Bobby talk outside in the cold.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: We've found beds for almost all the family. Truman is at Blair House. There was a brief crisis about him not having a driver, but Ike offered his. (beat) We're running a bed and breakfast. They share the faintest hint of a smile.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lyndon just wants to move into the Oval. He wants to address Congress. I'll hold him off as long as I can. But it has to happen sooner or later. Jackie doesn't answer, digesting the inevitable. Treading lightly --

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jackie... They're worried about an outdoor procession. They think it's a security risk. Everyone's spooked. Apparently even State's discouraging foreign dignitaries from attending. Jackie doesn’t respond. Trying to reason with her

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's eight city blocks to Saint Matthews. That's a long way to be strolling through crowds. (beat) All those rooftops. All those windows... Bobby trails off. Jackie holds his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: (firm) Bobby it’s our last chance. We have to march with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie sits alone, wearing a bathrobe, drinking VODKA in darkened room. Outside, night has fallen and all is quiet -- but she can sleep. Restless, she rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie steps inside another dark, still room. Pausing in the threshold, she listens for sound in the ha She's visibly tense, clearly a stranger to this space. Only when she’s confident that she’s alone does she take breath and look around -- at her husband’s private bedroo At the room’s center -- a four-poster bed, stained wood, masculine. Jackie walks to the edge of the empty bed. She’s dressed for her husband -- but he’s not there. She turns to the Victrola on the night stand and turns it As Camelot begins to play... Jackie moves to the BEDSIDE TABLE -- stacked high with BO and bottles of PAIN KILLERS.  43. One-by-one, she picks them up, reading the book’s spines medicine labels. She turns to the credenza -- a line of PHOTOS. President Kennedy with FAMILY, POLITICAL DIGNITARIES and MOVIE STAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie surveys her famous wardrobe. She takes a swig from her glass and sets it on the shelf. Then she drops her robe. Jackie pulls a Chanel gown off the rack and steps into it A beat, as she considers herself in the mirror. She's as gorgeous as ever, but she doesn’t like what she sees. Jackie steps out of the gown, leaving it on the floor. Another swig from that bottle and she pulls another dress from a hangar. And now, QUICK CUTS -- Jackie DRESSING and UNDRESSING, compulsively cycling thro her wardrobe of designer OUTFITS while she drinks. Also-- EARRINGS and NECKLACES, one-after-the-other, in a FRENZY. Finally, the bottle is EMPTY -- and a pile of discarded clothes lies at her feet. Now, Jackie stumbles to her DRESSING TABLE and takes out MAKE-UP. With an unsteady hand, she goes to work with her eyeliner lipstick and mascara. She rises and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slowly enters and approaches the President’s desk. She sits still in his seat, tears running down her face. Jackie stares into the distance -- as Camelot ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie sits facing the Journalist.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: How would you write that?

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: She lights yet another cigarette and through her soft sobs, explains -- Jack wasn’t perfect. But he was perfect for our country. (beat) And I ask about his flaws, and she explains--

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: (playing along) --Perfect people can’t change. Jack was always getting better... stronger. (beat) Sometimes he would walk into the desert, alone, just to let himself be tempted by the devil. But he always came back to us, his beloved family. A beat -- as Jackie exhales her cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I don’t smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie sits in the backseat of a limousine. Where - or wh -- we are isn't clear. Another ‘interview’ -- this one wi a PRIEST, who sits across from her.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I shouldn't say these things..

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: That's why you're here, isn't it? To talk about what happened?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Is this a confession?  45.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Only if there’s something you regret. Resisting...

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Everyone knows my story.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: God isn’t interested in stories. He’s interested in truth.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I came here looking for sympathy, Father.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Father, are you listening?

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: I’m listening. Yes, I think so. Their conversation moves to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie and the Priest walk down a long path.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I think God is cruel.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Well now you're getting into trouble. (beat) God is love. And God is everywhere. She has him trapped.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Was he in the bullet that killed Jack? All the Priest's answers are defiant and firm --

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Absolutely.  46.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Is he inside me right now?

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Yes. Of course he is.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: (weary) Well that’s a funny game he plays -- hiding all the time.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: The fact that we don’t understand him isn’t funny at all. LATER - on a bench now...

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: If there's a heaven, there's your God -- with all his empty promises. (angry) What kind of God takes a father from his two little children?!

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Thy Lord sacrificed his only son-- Jackie cuts off his pat reply -- She looks

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: --And my two babies. (beat) Arabella in the womb. And Patrick. Thirty-nine hours on this earth. Just long enough to fall in love with him. the Priest in the eyes, rage brimming over --

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What did I do to deserve that? A long beat, as he waits for her rage to subside -- and t summon an answer.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Nothing. Jackie falls into deeper resentment.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Jack and I hardly ever spent the night together. Not even that last night in Forth Worth.  47. The Priest treads lightly --

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Your husband loved you, Mrs. Kennedy. I’m sure of it.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: (bitter) I seem to remember there being more to our vows. The Priest looks at her with pity in his eyes. And it’s t one thing she can’t stand. She snaps --

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't look at me like that. (beat) I was First Lady of the United States. Women have been doing far worse for far less. A beat as it hangs there -- the Priest, taken aback by he candor.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There are two kinds of women. Those who want power in the world. And those who want power in bed. And then, lamenting the marital bargain she made --

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Of course, now what am I left with? When men see me now, what do you think they feel?

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Sadness. Compassion. (beat) Desire, maybe. You're still a young woman, Mrs. Kennedy.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I used to make them smile. (beat) No one understands the pain he was in and how loyal he was. Some of his friends were so crude. Jack wasn’t of course. But he could get caught up in it. Still...he was a great father. (beat) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I picture him in that rocking chair in his office. Caroline and John at his feet...How could I hate him?

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Take comfort in those memories.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I can’t. They're mixed up with all the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie is draped in black cloth -- in this case a silk sl Barely recovered from the night before, she chain smokes, while Nancy arranges her outfit on the bed. Jackie puts out one cigarette, and goes to light another. She catches Nancy's look of disapproval.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Do you have the latest list from the State Department? Off Nancy's confusion --

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Of the dignitaries planning to attend the funeral.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. I have it right here. Nancy rummages through some nearby files and finds the li She scans it --

dialogues.speaker: NANCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: General De Gaulle. Prince Phillip. Even the Soviet Foreign Minister.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: More than we were expecting?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. There are dozens of names. Jackie can’t help feel some pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Good. Will you read them to me?  49.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes. From the United Nations, there’s Paul Hoffmann. The King of Belgium. From Denmark, the crown prince George... Nancy reads the list as Jackie continues to smoke. The na go on and on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie now sits at her dressing table, Nancy trying to pl a veil on her hair.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I think you should just try it without it. Nancy strokes Jackie’s hair with her hand. Jackie rests h head on her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: (grateful) We've been together a long time, Haven't we, Nancy? (beat) I used to worry that you might be jealous of me.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh stop it.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: You never did anything to make me feel that way. But I worried. After I married Jack. And after he won the election. (beat) Now that seems ridiculous. Anyone being jealous of me. I've buried two children and now I’m burying my husband. Nancy isn’t sure how to respond. But she is no longer an employee -- just an old friend..

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You know I was jealous. Of that dress you wore in Vienna. Jackie smiles, grateful for the release.  50.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know it is hard to see it right now, but you have your whole life ahead of you. Rejecting the trite consolation --

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: That's a terrible thing to say. They both smile.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: But you do!

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: That's a terrible, terrible thing to say... Nancy comforts her. Holds her.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: But you do. I’m sorry. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: What will you do now?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh, I’1l stay with you.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: You won’t go anywhere?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: No, I'm not going anywhere. I don’t have anywhere to go. They share a welcome laugh.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Those kids are so lucky to have you.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: (between sobs) No, they’re not lucky at all. They're not lucky. I’m scared, Nancy, I’m scared, I’m scared...

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I know. I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: President Johnson, Lady Bird, Bobby, Ethel, and the rest the Kennedy family wait for Jackie and the children. Like the rest of the country, they watch the news...

dialogues.speaker: BRINKLEY, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: At the Capitol where the President's body will lie and stay for the remainder of the day after it has been removed from the White House, there will be three short speeches before the public is allowed to start viewing the body. To Dallas, Texas and Tom Pettit... Mary enters the room and announces...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: She'll be right down. I'm told any moment. No one turns away from the TV. President Johnson looks at his watch. ON TV: A MAN steps into the frame, blocking the camera, a then rushes out of the way. Suddenly a flurry of activity PHOTOGRAPHERS race into position, and DETECTIVES in Stets hats emerge from the corridor. REPORTERS surge forward, blocking the camera again...

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: (on TV) There is Lee Oswald -- And then -- RUBY runs across the screen and fires.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (on TV) He’s been shot. He’s been shot. Lee Oswald has been shot. There’s a man with a gun! Off the BANG! of the fatal SHOT, the phone immediately RI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie helps John Jr with his tie.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Are you ready to go?  52. JOHN JR. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Will you look at me? JOHN JR. Mommy, is it my birthday?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Not yet, dear. She kisses his forehead and holds his face. From the doorway, announcing himself --

dialogues.speaker: HILL
dialogues.text: Special Agent Hill. Whenever Mrs. Kennedy is ready.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Oh Clint... We're nearly done here. Jackie rises to greet him. But as she locks eyes with him she seems to falter on her feet. She stares at him, trying to recapture some lost memory.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s the strangest thing. I hardly remember anything after. (beat) But I've read about what you did in the papers. And I just wanted to thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHAOS in the wake of Oswald's assassination.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT JOHNSON
dialogues.text: (increasingly enraged) We need to get a handle on this thing. We've got to get involved.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTI
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT JOHNSON
dialogues.text: This is making us look like a bunch of goddamn barbarians!  53. Mary announces...

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (horrified) Mrs. Kennedy is on her way down. With the children.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Turn the television off! (he does) You're not to speak a word of this. Understood? I'll tell Jackie when the time is right. The group remains frozen in horror. BOBBY (CONT’D) (to Johnson) sit down.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT JOHNSON
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: sit down.

dialogues.speaker: LADY BIRD
dialogues.text: Darling? President Johnson sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie continues speaking to Hill.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: What do you remember? Will you tell me everything. I need to hear. He sees the desperation in her eyes. Has no choice...

dialogues.speaker: HILL
dialogues.text: I was ten yards back when I heard the first shot. As my eyes crossed the President’s car... He hesitates to continue.

dialogues.speaker: HILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kennedy...

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Keep going.  54.

dialogues.speaker: HILL
dialogues.text: I had to get to you to put myself between you the President and the shooter.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Who was it? Was it that Oswald?

dialogues.speaker: HILL
dialogues.text: They think so.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I need to talk to him. (beat) I need to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: HILL
dialogues.text: (nervous) I don’t know about that, Mrs. Kennedy. For a moment, they just stand in silence. And then --

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: The children are ready. Shall I take them downstairs to ride with Maud?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I'd like them to come with me.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: The press is out front. I thought you'd prefer --

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Their father is leaving this house for the last time. They should be there to say goodbye to him.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: But the cameras? Those pictures are being broadcast to every corner of the world. Jackie has found some burst of strength in her encounter Hill.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Those pictures should record the truth. Two heartbroken, fatherless children are a part of that. (beat) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can tell them I’m ready to leave -- with Caroline and John. Nancy is taken aback by her intensity.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes, Mrs. Kennedy. As Nancy turns to leave --

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Nancy?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I’m not the First Lady anymore. (beat) You can call me Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I will. Jackie turns back to the children.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Caroline, are you ready sweetheart? She goes to pick up her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My brave girl. And now John begins to sob. She reaches for her son.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, John, John, John -- Off his cries...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie sits with the Journalist at the table.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I value my privacy. I always have.  56.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: And yet in the days after -- directly after -- something seemed to change.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: In what way?

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Before the funeral. The day you moved the casket to the Capitol. Your children were on full display for the whole world to see.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: What are you insinuating? That I exploited them?

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: No, of course not...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie leads Caroline and John Jr out onto the PORTICO, squinting in the mid-day sun. She takes in the extraordinary scene. The horse-drawn CAISSON carrying the President's flag-dra CASKET is parked just before them, followed by a RIDERLES HORSE, and then a train of LIMOUSINES to carry the mourne In the lead is a DRUM CORPS. The WHITE HOUSE DRIVE is lined by parallel rows of SOLDIE carrying the flags of the 50 states. The WHITE HOUSE LAWN is crowded with CAMERA CREWS, REPORT and STAFF. All are reverent, silent. FLASHBULBS erupt, capturing the indelible image... The wi in black. The two innocent children in powder blue. They are still, and now frozen in time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie looks out at the crowd of mourners lining the stre Their reflection scrolls by her face in the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Journalist is now on the offensive.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: I’m only wondering if you considered doing more to shield them. I think most people would have--

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: We aren’t ‘most people’. (beat) Most people don’t have to make those kinds of decisions, hours after watching their husband get murdered next to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The caisson comes to a stop at the base of the SENATE STE the trail of LIMOUSINES just behind. An HONOR GUARD and a NAVY BAND wait to receive them. The doors of the limousines open, and Jackie steps out, a with Caroline, John Jr and Bobby. President Johnson and Lady Bird emerge from the next car, take up position beside them. Jackie turns to the new PRESIDENT...

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Oh, Lyndon. What an awful way to begin your presidency. Before he can reply, she walks ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long beat, and then --

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Are you saying it was a mistake?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: No, of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie and Caroline follow the casket to the catafalque. Bobby helps John Jr to a seat in the first row. The HONOR GUARD steps aside and the room silently watches Jackie kneels, and Caroline kneels beside her. Jackie presses her lips gently against the flag. Caroline follows.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. BOBBY’S OFFICE - WHITE HOUSE Bobby is back at his desk on the phone. Jackie storms int his office. Her eyes are wild -- brimming with a rage we' never seen.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: How dare you?!

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Jackie-- She charges toward him. He hangs up the phone --

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: They murdered him!! Inside the jail! These people can get to anyone!

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: We don't know--

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: --How dare you keep that from me?!

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: We didn't know any of the details. And the ceremony at the Capitol... We had to keep moving--

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: You had no right! The children! I took them out the front door! She physically shudders at the thought of it...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Are you--  59.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: --This is all insanity!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to reach for her, but she backs away--

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You and your brother. All these years, all your goddamn secrets!

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: That's not fair...

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Caroline and John are all I have left. And I put them in danger because of you--

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I would never put you at risk--

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: --You can't know that! You think you all control everything. That you have the world on puppet strings. You’re ridiculous! And I let myself believe it. (beat) And this parade? Who is it really for? For Jack? One more campaign stop along the way to the grave?! (beat) Lyndon's people are right. It's not worth it! It's not worth risking people's lives! Bobby doesn't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You tell them we're calling it off. (beat) We'll motorcade to the Cathedral. The back way. We'll bury him. And we'll put an end to all this. I don't give a damn anymore.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: We would never put you and your children in--

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I know you think I’m some silly little debutante--  60.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: --Listen to me.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: You don’t protect me, anymore!

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I would never put you and the children in danger.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: You don’t know anything. She turns and leaves him standing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie walks with the Priest.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I lie awake at night and all I can think is...I wish I’d been a shop girl, or a stenographer. I should have married an ordinary, lazy, ugly man. The Priest studies her -- considers the depth of her suffering. He tries one more time to get through --

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Let me share with you a parable. (beat) Jesus once passed a blind beggar on the road, and his disciples asked -- ‘Who sinned, this man or his parents, that he should be born blind?’ (beat) Jesus answered - ‘Neither this man nor his parents sinned. He was made blind so that the works of God could be revealed in him.’ (beat) And with that, he placed mud on the man’s eyes and told him to wash in the Pool of Siloam.’ The man did, and he came back seeing. (beat) Right now you are blind. Not because you’ve sinned. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But because you've been chosen -- so that the works of God may be revealed in you. A long beat of silence, as Jackie stares back at the Prie still unsatisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The morning sun peaks through the edges of the drawn curtains, but the Oval Office is dim and vacant. Jackie is on her knees, in a new black dress, freshly showered, but still groggy. She is surrounded by the RESOLUTE DESK, which John Jr was famously photographed playing beneath. The COCONUT the PRESIDENT used to scrawl a rescue message when his boat was sunk in the South Pacific. The MODEL of the naval vessel, The Danmark, he meticulous constructed. And finally -- the ROCKING CHAIR where he used to sit, th children playing at his feet. She runs her hand across the NEW CARPET, pleased.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: It's perfect.

dialogues.speaker: WALTON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We installed it while you were away. Walton stands in the doorway. WALTON (CONT’D) I thought it would be a nice surprise for you and the President. Jackie rises.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: It changes everything. She stands, admiring her handiwork.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And the Treaty Room?  62.

dialogues.speaker: WALTON
dialogues.text: Hunter green. Exactly as you imagined it.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I wish Jack... She trails off. And then--
