dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who knows if he would have cared. She laughs, bitterly.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I lost track, somewhere. What was real. What was performance.

dialogues.speaker: WALTON
dialogues.text: Well, he was a President. A beat, and then --

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: You were right earlier. (beat) I've told them I'm not going to march tomorrow. I won't put people in danger on account of my vanity.

dialogues.speaker: WALTON
dialogues.text: I was scared for you. I still am. But I never thought it was vanity. Jackie gestures to the redecorated room --

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: You know, that's what Jack called all this. When he saw what we were spending. He said your little ‘vanity project' is going to bankrupt the federal government. This is Walton's life's work, his purpose for being --

dialogues.speaker: WALTON
dialogues.text: People need their history. It gives them strength. They need to know that real men actually lived here. Not ghosts and storybook legends. People who faced adversity and overcame it. (beat) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: WALTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What you've done in this house matters. Jackie considers his words. They've struck a chord, but she's still not convinced.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: That's kind of you, Bill. But even I'm starting to lose him. (beat, she stands) Pretty soon, he'll just be another oil portrait lining these hallways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie holds a cake as a Secret Service member lights the third and final candle. She enters the room to join Nancy, Maud, and Caroline celebrating John Jr’s 3rd birthday. She sings...

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Happy Birthday to you, Happy Birthday to you, Happy Birthday Dear John, Happy Birthday to YOu... John blows out the candles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie sits at the edge of Lincoln's arched mahogany bed, staring up at the portrait of Mary Todd that hangs above Outside, the sun is setting. Bobby enters the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I spoke to Johnson. (beat) Tomorrow...it's being handled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone will ride. No procession. Jackie nods. Bobby slowly sits beside her, utterly defeat

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Bobby. A moment of silence, and then, gesturing to the portrait.  64.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you think Lincoln's widow knew?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: That we'd build a monument to her husband? Bobby doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why is this room so peaceful? A long pause.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Peaceful? (beat) Every time I walk by this room I'm reminded that on January 1, 1863, an ordinary man signed a document that freed four million people from slavery. (beat) So I don’t think of it so much as ‘peaceful’, but as a place of profound legacy. (beat) And it’s too bad that ours is totally fucking wasted. He turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Bobby! He slams the door shut and turns back to her.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bobby, watch your mouth--

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What did we accomplish?! We're just the beautiful people? Is that what we are?!

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Bobby!  65.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What did we truly accomplish? Maybe Jack will be remembered for the way he handled the missile crisis. Or maybe he’1l be remembered for creating the crisis in the first place... He sits next to her. BOBBY (CONT’D) We could have done so much. Civil Rights, the space program. vietnam... (beat) We teed up Vietnam. Now Johnson gets to knock it down. (beat, one more regret) I shouldn’t have pushed him so hard on Castro.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: You can’t do that, Bobby. He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What's wrong with you? He stands.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: What's wrong with me?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: History is harsh. We're ridiculous. Look at you... As he walks away...

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie enters to find workers packing up her husband's belongings. His books. His rocking chair. INT. JACKIE’S BEDROOM - WHITE HOUSE More workers pack as she clings to an antique turquoise v reluctant to let go.  66.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Starting to give in, Jackie tosses a doll into a box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie throws a heap of her dresses into a box. She tapes the box closed - but the tape catches on her wedding ring. Angry, shaking, she struggles to take the ring off. Jackie swallows a pill. She catches a glimpse of herself in the mirror. Lingers.. INT. BOBBY’S OFFICE - WHITE HOUSE Johnson's top aide, Jack Valenti unpacks his belongings i Bobby’s old office. He's interrupted by --

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: How do you like your new office? Jackie stands in his doorway.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTI
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kennedy. Come in. Sorry I’m just trying to do my job ma’am. She knows the jab was unfair.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: (sincere) Of course you are. I remember when we won the election, how overwhelming it was.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTI
dialogues.text: Everyone's thoughts are with you right now. Jackie smiles graciously.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: That's very kind of you. (beat) I've come to discuss tomorrow.  Valenti is He catches 67.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTI
dialogues.text: The Attorney General relayed to me your desire for a more modest ceremony.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I've changed my mind.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTI
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I said I've changed my mind. we will have the procession. And I will walk to the Cathedral. With the casket. stunned.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTI
dialogues.text: Well even if we could resume the arrangements, I'm sure you can understand... The Secret Service still has their concerns.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: And President Johnson?

dialogues.speaker: VALENTI
dialogues.text: President Johnson would like nothing more than to fulfill your wishes. But, I have to take into account his safety. The country couldn't endure another blow should anything-- himself.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I didn't mean... If it were up to him, he'd do anything that might bring you comfort.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Then, who is it up to, Mr. Valenti?

dialogues.speaker: VALENTI
dialogues.text: As I’m sure you know, we're expecting close to a hundred Heads of State.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: One hundred three.  68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surprised by her precision

dialogues.speaker: VALENTI
dialogues.text: Yes. I’m sure that’s right. (beat) And I suspect they'll all make their own decisions.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Based on what? Trying to intimidate her --

dialogues.speaker: VALENTI
dialogues.text: There’s a great deal of classified intelligence that I can’t get into. Jackie stares at him, unimpressed, and he knows he’1l hav give her more than that.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We've intercepted a threat against General De Gaulle. From our assets in Geneva. (beat) I'm afraid if he refuses to march, others may follow. Jackie considers this. Seeming to waver --

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: (sympathetic) I understand. Valenti thinks he’s won.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTI
dialogues.text: As I said, Mrs. Kennedy I wish there were more we could do to accommodate your wishes. (beat) I’m terribly sorry. Jackie seems to accept this.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Don’t be. You and the Johnson's have already done so much.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTI
dialogues.text: Good day, Mrs. Kennedy. Jackie turns to go -.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: then stops in the doorway.  69.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Mr. Valenti. Would you mind getting a message to all the funeral guests when they land? Not sure where this is going --

dialogues.speaker: VALENTI
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Inform them that I will walk with Jack tomorrow. (beat) Alone if necessary. (beat) And tell General De Gaulle -- if he wishes to ride in an armored car -- or in a tank for that matter -- I won't blame him. (beat) And I’m sure the tens of millions of people watching won't either. She turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTI
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this Mrs. Kennedy?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m just doing my job. With that, Jackie exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie and the Journalist sit across from each other.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Would you like to write this down?

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Do you think I should?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I... I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Journalist opens his notebook to a blank page and beg to take dictation  70.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We all live on far after our deaths. Presidents will come and go and every one of them will look up to Jack for guidance, for inspiration. He finishes writing the paragraph.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: What do you say to those who say he didn’t deserve it? The scale of it? (off her confusion) He was a great President -- but he didn’t win the Civil war, for instance.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: It was a funeral for the President of the United States.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Your husband drove cars, he didn’t ride horses. An outburst --

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Yes and there should have been more of them. There should have been more horses, more soldiers, more crying, more cameras!

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: I’m guessing you won't allow me to write any of that?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: No, because I never said that. (beat) Perhaps Jack didn’t have time to defeat Communism--

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: --with all due respect, you were at the center of it all Mrs. Kennedy. (beat) And I'd imagine, from that vantage, it was impossible to have any perspective. (beat) But I can assure you -- it was a spectacle.  T1. And now INTERCUT -- the FUNERAL PROCESSION, the Journalis and the Priest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The caisson comes to a stop in front of the White House. ANGLE UP to Jackie, peering out at the assembled crowd. JACKIE'S POV -- looking down on Bobby and Ethel. Ted and Joan, Janet and Hugh Auchincloss. Sargent and Eunice Shriver. O’Brien, O'Donnell, and Powers. President and Lady Bird Johnson. Behind them is a pantheon of foreign leaders. De Gaulle, EMPEROR HAILE SELASSIE of Ethiopia, PRINCE PHILLIP, DUKE

dialogues.speaker: EDINBURGH, SOVIET FOREIGN MINISTER ANASTAS MIKOYAN, JEAN
dialogues.text: MONNET and others. It is an extraordinary gathering -- manifest only through Jackie's force of will. A long beat, as she takes it all in. In her eyes -- the faintest hint of pride behind the sadness. Finally, Jackie steps forward and takes her place between Bobby and Ted. She wears a veil over her face -- and the BLACK WATCH PIPERS begin their plaintive dirge... The caisson lurches forward, pulled by a train of WHITE STALLIONS, and the grim parade begins... As they exit the White House Gates, Jackie looks down PENNSYLVANIA and for the first time comes face-to-face wi the scope of the nation's sorrow. All the way to the distant horizon, the sidewalks are overflowing with MOURNERS.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Nancy said they wanted to share my grief.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: So I let them. She continues to speak with the Priest.  72.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But after, I realized...all the pageantry, all the demands I made to honor him. It wasn't for Jack. Or his legacy. (beat) It_was for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie pauses and we ANGLE ON... Hill, tensing up beside He scans the crowd for threats as POLICE OFFICERS on the line snap to attention. ANGLE WIDE, REVEALING -- the long, empty street ahead. Quick CLOSE-UPS: A MAN IN A FEDORA. A BLACK MAN. A WOMAN and CHILD. Threats? Or grieving citizens? In the back of a black car, John Jr and Caroline ride in procession, looking out at the crowd through the rear win Jackie takes a step and continues bravely marching forwar

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I wrote him a letter. That night, before we moved the casket to the Capitol. Do you know what I wrote?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: That I wanted to die.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: (empathetic) I understand.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: (skeptical) Do you?

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: I do. Unless you are asking my permission.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: No, only crass, self-indulgent people kill themselves. (beat) I was just hoping... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: if I walked down the street next to Jack's body maybe someone would be kind enough to do it for me.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: In front of the whole world... A famous life, a famous death.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I never wanted fame. I just became a Kennedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie continues to lead the march. Bobby flanking her. Mourners watching from the windows. Hats over their heart

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I've told everyone that I can't remember. (beat) But that's not true. I can remember. I can remember everything. And now, finally, we see the ASSASSINATION -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie is back in that limousine in Dallas. She waves to cheering crowd.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: The first bullet. (beat) Boom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this time -- the sequence continues: CLOSE ON Jackie -- everything that now follows tracking h experience.  74. BANG! -- Jackie startles, confused. (In her mind, this wa the missed opportunity to act.)

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Then boom. BANG! -- Jackie turns -- eyes widening in horror as the President grips his throat. She's about to reach for him— And BANG! -- she is showered in BLOOD and GRAY MATTER as head explodes all over her.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I could have saved him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie panics -- climbing out of her seat, onto the back the still-moving car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She claws her way to the rear-bumper, hanging on for her life.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I should have known it was a gunshot. I should have shielded him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bagpipers march. Marines stand in formation.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I tried to stop the bleeding. But by the time we got to the hospital it was... She stands, watching through her black veil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON Jackie -- back in the car, where her husband’s b is slumped over, BLOOD pooling everywhere.  15. Jackie resists, but Hill shoves her down into the carnage shielding her body with his. Jackie lies prone, sandwiched between Hill and her dying husband -- trapped in an unspeakable, visceral horror. Jackie reaches out for Jack's head -- and tries to hold together his shattered skull. We stay with her -- as the car now accelerates toward the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: That night, and every night since... I’ve prayed to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The casket is carried through the mourners gathered.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Won't God let me be with my husband? Marines fold the flag and hand it to her. She stands staring at the casket. Remembering the horror the limo as it sped with his head in her hands. The casket is lowered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie sits with the Journalist.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Can I look? She slides Field’s notes to her side of the table.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: It's just, I haven’t--

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: You don’t write very legibly, do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: you? He watches her read.  76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Journalist paces as Jackie rewrites furiously.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: You left your mark on this country, Mrs. Kennedy. These past few days...That’s the story. (long beat) Losing a President is like losing a father. And you were a mother to all of us. And that’s a very good story. (beat) The entire country watched the funeral from beginning to end. Decades from now, people will remember your dignity, and the majesty... (beat) They'll remember you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Collingswood and Jackie have reached the end of the tour the Monroe Room on the second floor.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: It will serve a definite purpose. (beat) My husband has so many meetings up here, in this part of the house. All the men who wait to see him, now sit in the hall, with baby carriages going by them. So they can sit in here and have a conference around this table, waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINGSWOOD
dialogues.text: Well, he’s going to come in and-- PRESIDENT KENNEDY -- handsome, resplendent -- enters the room. COLLINGSWOOD (CONT’D) (excited) Mister president... They shake hands.  71.

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT KENNEDY
dialogues.text: Mister Collingswood.

dialogues.speaker: COLLINGSWOOD
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kennedy has been showing us about the White House and all the changes she has made therein. What do you think of the changes that she’s made?

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT KENNEDY
dialogues.text: Well, I think that the great effort she’s made has been to bring us much more intimately in contact with all the men who lived here. Of course, I think anyone who comes to the White House as a President desires the best for his country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy leads Jackie down the stairs, out of the White Hous for the last time...

dialogues.speaker: PRESIDENT KENNEDY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And I think he receives stimulus from the knowledge of living in close proximity to the people who are legendary but who actually were alive and were in these rooms. Jackie notices -- down the hallway, Lady Bird reviews new fabric swatches with Walton. Walton catches her glance. A hint of shame in his eyes -- but this is no longer her home. Jackie looks down and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caroline and John Jr head into a waiting limousine. All around them, the chaos of the MOVERS continues.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Everything will be held in storage until you decide where to settle. The two women embrace. Jackie finally enters the car.  78. She looks back through the window to the home she devoted much of her life. Echoing the first scene of the White House tour -~ Nancy encourages her to smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Journalist watches Jackie from across the room.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: There’s one last thing -- more important than all the rest... (beat) You know every night before bed, we had this old Victrola. We'd listen to a couple records. And his favorite was Camelot.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: The musical?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm so ashamed of myself. Every quote out of Jack’s mouth was either Greek or Roman. And that last song, that last side of Camelot is all that keeps running through my mind. (beat) "Don't let it be forgot, that for one brief shining moment there was a Camelot."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A boisterous, glamorous party is in full swing. Jackie la in a red regal dress with elbow-length white gloves. President Kennedy grabs her hand and they dance.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jack loved history. It’s what made him what he was. Imagine him... this little boy, with scarlet fever in bed, reading history. (beat) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: King Arthur and the Knights of the Round Table. That’s what Camelot is about. Ordinary men banding together to fight for a better world. Don't misunderstand me... (beat) Jack wasn't naive. But, he had ideals. Ideals he could rally others to believe in.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: And will those ideals live on?

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I’m sure they will. Of course there will be other great Presidents. The Johnson's have been so generous to me. (beat) But there won't be another Camelot. Not another Camelot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Priest and Jackie sit at an impasse, their talk comin an end with no resolution. Slowly and deliberately, the Priest’s face darkens -- his tone sharpening.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Why are you really here? An awkward silence, Jackie taken aback--

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I--I needed to talk.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: You say you pray every night to die. That your children have no use for you. That you wish only to be with your husband. (beat) And yet -- I’m not burying you today. (beat) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There comes a time in man’s search for meaning, when one realizes -- there are no answers. (beat) When you come to that horrible, unavoidable realization -- you accept it. Or you kill yourself. Or you simply stop searching. Jackie is reeling--

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have lived a blessed life. and yet every night when I climb into bed, turn off the lights, and stare into the dark, I wonder...is this all there is? Jackie’s tone softens -- the Priest’s honesty finally get through to her...

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: You wonder? The Priest nods --

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Every soul on this planet does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie playfully runs after Caroline and John Jr.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And then, when morning comes, we all wake up and make a pot of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Why do we bother? She catches up to John Jr and picks him up. Twirls him.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Because we do. You did this morning, and you will again tomorrow. Jackie stops to watch her laughing children.  81.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: God, in his infinite wisdom, has made sure...it is just enough for us. Jackie looks on as Caroline and John Jr build sand castle under gray skies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Journalist dictates his article to his editor...

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST, (INTO PHONE)
dialogues.text: Once more... Mrs. Kennedy has expressed her desire to reinter the bodies of the two children they lost to rest alongside their father. (beat) You got that part, right? (beat) She wants them to always remember, for one brief shining moment there was a-- yeah, Camelot. Yeah. Finally, the Journalist hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: JOURNALIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I hope you have a good night, Mrs. Kennedy. A moment of silence between them. And he exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie relates to the Priest, with some satisfaction --

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: He wrote down every word.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: And did that help... Heal you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie thinks. Not exactly an answer:

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: It's been reprinted all over the world. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe that’s what they'll all believe now. (beat) Camelot. (beat) People like to believe in fairy tales.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: And you? Do you believe you've done him justice? Jackie can’t bring herself to say yes. Instead --

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I believe the characters we read about on the page end up being more real than the men who stand beside us. (beat) I should have guessed it was too much to ask that we grow old together. See our children grow up. The Priest studies her -- hoping she’s slowly making her toward some semblance of solace. But it’s clear -- she’s not yet there.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: The darkness may never go away. But it won’t always be this heavy. Come. They’re waiting for us at Arlington. cUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Eternal Flame burns over President Kennedy's grave -- fresh, small graves dug beside it. Patrick Bouvier Kennedy. August 17, 1963 - August 19, 196 Daughter. 1956.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: -.. the Father, the Son, the Holy Spirit...  83. Jackie watches another tiny casket lowered into the groun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walton mounts a plaque outside Jackie’s bedroom. It reads "In this room lived John Fitzgerald Kennedy and his wife, Jacqueline, during the two years, ten months, and two day was President of the United States: January 20, 1961 - November 22, 1963."

dialogues.speaker: I/E. JACKIE'S MOTORCADE WASHINGTON, DC NIGHT
dialogues.text: Jackie looks out the window at the now-quiet streets. We hear Camelot begin to play... “Each evening from December to December, before you drift sleep upon your cot / Think back on all the tales that yo will remember...of Camelot...” The limo slows and Jackie notices: Across the street shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAN is carrying a MANNEQUIN over his Porcelain skin. Jet-black bouffant. Perfectly symmetrical features. Jackie stares at a perfect plastic reproduction of hersel A surreal, disorienting moment. And then ANOTHER MAN, carrying another, identical, MANNEQ Jackie tracks them back to a nearby TRUCK -- where WORKER unload DOZENS more of them. The workers carry the dolls into a MACY’S DEPARTMENT STOR In the store windows -- STYLISTS dress the mannequins in reproductions of the outfits Jackie has been wearing for past five days. Jackie stares in disbelief at her own image frozen in tim the widow, forever in mourning.  84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie and Collingswood continue their tour in front of t cameras. (Camelot continues to play...)

dialogues.speaker: JACKIE
dialogues.text: I'm just so happy that he could be proud. Because then I was having a baby and I couldn’t campaign and then we got in the White House and all the things I’d always done, suddenly they became wonderful. And I was just so happy for Jack that he could be proud of me. (beat) Those were our happiest years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie is seated between President Kennedy and Bobby. Pablo Casals finishes his performance of Felix Mendelssoh Piano Trio No. 1 in D minor, Op. 49. A standing ovation. Jackie gives Casals her gloved hand to kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie dances in her red dress with President Kennedy. She rests her head on his shoulder as Camelot finally crescendoes. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
